 Actually, it dates back to WW2, when wage freezes prompted all manufacturers to offer increased benefits to attract employees in a highly competitive labor market. Following WW2, due to their non-taxable status, it was less expensive to grant increased benefits in union negotiations and for employees to accept them in lieu of larger wage increases. Companies liked that because not only was there a tax savings which enhanced unit margin without being passed on to the consumer, the liability could be carried on the balance sheet without affecting cash flow reserves. Quarterly and annual ROI have always driven US companies due to their equity market relationships, at the cost of effective long-range planning.
